facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated November 25, 1969 of Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 6201 of 1969.

facts.text: Appellant was an officer of the old State of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was an officer of the old State of Mysore.

facts.text: After States Reorganisation Act of 1956, appellant entered service of new State of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: After the States Reorganisation Act of 1956, he entered service of the new State of Mysore companystituted under that Act.

facts.text: Appellant entitled to benefits of Mysore Services Regulations as they stood on 1 November 1956.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that the appellant was entitled to the benefits of the service rules which obtained before his transfer to the new State of Mysore. The relevant rules are the Mysore Services, Regulations as they stood on 1 November 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Art. 305 of the Seventh Edition An officer in superior service, who has attained the age of fifty-five years, may be required to retire,  1  1960 1 S.C.R. 981.  2  11966 1 S.C.R. 994. anchor.surface_text: Rule 2046 of the Indian Railway Fundamental Rules as amended on 11 January 1967 provided, inter-alia, that if a ministerial railway servant, who entered Government service on or before 31 March 1938 and held on that date  i  a lien or a suspended lien on a permanent post, or  ii  a permanent posit in a provisional substantive capacity and companytinued to hold the same without interruption until be was companyfirmed in that post, he was to be retained in service till he attains the age of 60 years.

issues.text: what is the superannuation age of the appellant ?

anchor.surface_text: The question-that has arisen is what is the superannuation age of the appellant ? It is admitted that the appellant was entitled to the benefits of the service rules which obtained before his transfer to the new State of Mysore.

issues.text: whether the latest decision of this Court in Union of India and ors. v. R. V. Sadasiva Murthy etc. which has supported the petitioners case of 60 years being the age of superannuation rested on the effect of clause c of the old Art. 305

anchor.surface_text: According to the High Court the latest decision of this Court in Union of India and ors. v. R. V. Sadasiva Murthy etc. 3 which has supported the petitioners case of 60 years being the age of superannuation rested on the effect of clause c of the old Art. 305.

issues.text: whether Art. 428 of the Seventh Edition which is essentially a rule regarding pension supports the contention that the normal age of superannuation is 60 years

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, it is not necessary for us, to examine the question whether Art. 428 of the Seventh Edition which is essentially a rule regarding pension supports the contention that the normal age of superannuation is 60 years.

issues.text: whether the conditions of service governing the services of the appellant are those contained in the Eighth Edition

anchor.surface_text: First, it appears from the judgment of the High Court of Mysore that it was a common ground of the parties to the instant case that the conditions of service governing the services of the appellant are those contained in the Eighth Edition.

issues.text: whether Rule 2046 of the Indian Railway Fundamental Rules applies to the appellant

anchor.surface_text: Rule 2046 of the Indian Railway Fundamental Rules as amended on 11 January 1967 provided, inter-alia, that if a ministerial railway servant, who entered Government service on or before 31 March 1938 and held on that date i a lien or a suspended lien on a permanent post, or ii a permanent posit in a provisional substantive capacity and continued to hold the same without interruption until be was confirmed in that post, he was to be retained in service till he attains the age of 60 years.

issues.text: under Art. 294(a) the age of retirement is 55 years

anchor.surface_text: This Court rejected that contention and held first, that under Art. 294(a) the age of retirement is 55 years and, secondly, Art. 297 which is complementary to Art. 294(a) allows the government servant, if the Government wants to keep him in service after 55. to opt for retirement.

arguments.court_reasoning: No need to examine effect of Art. 428 or clause c as other grounds suffice; distinguishes Sadasiva differently

arguments.claim: Sadasiva Murthy distinguishable from earlier decisions because Art. 305 of Seventh Edition contained clause c (ruling to read with Art. 428 implying retirement before 60 only for inefficiency) omitted in Eighth Edition's Art. 294

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court an attempt was made on behalf of the State to explain the difference between the latest decision of this Court and the two earlier decisions by pointing out that Art. 305 of the Seventh Edition contained a ruling of the Government which indicated that Art. 305 and Art. 428 should be read together. It was contended that Art. 428 suggests that an officer in the superior service could be retired before reaching 60 years only on the ground of inefficiency. The argument was that this clause c which attracts the operation of Art. 428 was omitted in the Eight Edition and Art. 294 of that Edition standing by itself indicated 55 years to be the age of superannuation.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ain the difference between the latest decision of

arguments.court_reasoning: Court finds it unnecessary to examine whether Art. 428 supports 60 years normal age

arguments.claim: The two earlier decisions (Narasimhachar and Padmanabhacharya) are more apposite as parties agree conditions of service are those in Eighth Edition which those cases construed

anchor.surface_text: So far as the instant case is concerned, we consider the two earlier decisions to be more apposite for two reasons. First, it appears from the judgment of the High Court of Mysore that it was a common ground of the parties to the instant case that the conditions of service governing the services of the appellant are those contained in the Eighth Edition. Since in the two earlier decisions it was the rule of the Eighth Edition which was construed those are the decisions with which we are concerned directly in the instant case.

arguments.claim: Sadasiva Murthy decision supported on different ground: Rule 2046 Indian Railway Fundamental Rules required retention till 60 for qualifying ministerial railway servants like Sadasiva but appellant not railway officer

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, the decision in the latest case may be supported on an entirely different ground. Rule 2046 of the Indian Railway Fundamental Rules as amended on 11 January 1967 provided, inter-alia, that if a ministerial railway servant, who entered Government service on or before 31 March 1938 and held on that date i a lien or a suspended lien on a permanent post, or ii a permanent post in a provisional substantive capacity and continued to hold the same without interruption until he was confirmed in that post, he was to be retained in service till he attains the age of 60 years.

arguments.claim: Art. 294(a) of Eighth Edition gives clear discretion to Government to require retirement at 55 years for superior or inferior service unless considers efficient and permits to remain; no option for officer and no obligation on Government to retain

arguments.court_reasoning: Directly follows interpretation of Art. 294 in earlier binding precedents and plain text

arguments.claim: Art. 297 indicates option is with public servant to retire at 55 or not, so government cannot retire at 55

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, in particular, relied on Art. 297 of the Mysore Services Regulations which laid down that a government servant in superior services who has attained the age of 55 years, may at his option retire from the service on his superannuation pension. The petitioner urged that Art. 297 indicated clearly that the option is with the public servant whether he retires at the age of 55 years or not.

holdings.text: The conditions of service governing the services of the appellant are those contained in the Eighth Edition of the Mysore Services Regulations.

anchor.surface_text: it was a common ground of the parties to the instant case that the conditions of service governing the services of the appellant are those contained in the Eighth Edition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepted as common ground of parties noted in High Court judgment; directly relevant as earlier precedents interpret Eighth Edition.

holdings.text: The two earlier decisions of this Court (Narasimhachar and Padmanabhacharya) interpreting Art. 294 of the Eighth Edition are more apposite than Sadasiva Murthy.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the instant case is concerned, we consider the two earlier decisions to be more apposite for two reasons. First, it appears from the judgment of the High Court of Mysore that it was a common ground of the parties to the instant case that the conditions of service governing the services of the appellant are those contained in the Eighth Edition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Eighth Edition applies per agreement; those cases directly construe Art. 294 of that edition.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to examine whether Art. 428 of the Seventh Edition supports normal superannuation age of 60 years.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, it is not necessary for us, to examine the question whether Art. 428 of the Seventh Edition which is essentially a rule regarding pension supports the contention that the normal age of superannuation is 60 years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary as other grounds suffice for instant case under Eighth Edition.

holdings.text: Rule 2046 of the Indian Railway Fundamental Rules does not apply to the appellant as he is not a railway officer.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 2046 of the Indian Railway Fundamental Rules as amended on 11 January 1967 provided, inter-alia, that if a ministerial railway servant, who entered Government service on or before 31 March 1938 and held on that date i a lien or a suspended lien on a permanent post, or ii a permanent posit in a provisional substantive capacity and continued to hold the same without interruption until be was confirmed in that post, he was to be retained in service till he attains the age of 60 years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant not a railway officer and does not claim benefit of the rule applicable to qualifying ministerial railway servants like Sadasiva Murthy.

holdings.text: Under Art. 294(a) of the Eighth Edition, Government has discretion to require retirement of government servants in superior or inferior service at age 55 years unless it considers them efficient and permits retention; no obligation to extend service and officers have no option.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual interpretation of Art. 294(a); consistent with earlier Supreme Court decisions directly on point (Narasimhachar, Padmanabhacharya); distinguishes Sadasiva Murthy.

holdings.text: There is no merit in the appeal and it is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we do not think there is any merit in the appeal which is accordingly dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of above holdings to facts; superannuation age 55 under applicable Art. 294(a).

edges.explanation: The holding explicitly evaluates the relevance of Sadasiva Murthy compared to earlier decisions, directly addressing the issue of whether Sadasiva Murthy supports the petitioners' case for 60 years superannuation age.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the instant case is concerned, we consider the two earlier decisions to be more apposite for two reasons. First, it appears from the judgment of the High Court of Mysore that it was a common ground of the parties to the instant case that the conditions of service governing the services of the appellant are those contained in the Eighth Edition.
In these circumstances we do number think there is any merit in the appeal which is accordingly dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, it is not necessary for us, to examine the question whether Art. 428 of the Seventh Edition which is essentially a rule regarding pension supports the contention that the normal age of superannuation is 60 years.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 2046 of the Indian Railway Fundamental Rules as amended on 11 January 1967 provided, inter-alia, that if a ministerial railway servant, who entered Government service on or before 31 March 1938 and held on that date i a lien or a suspended lien on a permanent post, or ii a permanent posit in a provisional substantive capacity and continued to hold the same without interruption until be was confirmed in that post, he was to be retained in service till he attains the age of 60 years.
In these circumstances we do number think there is any merit in the appeal which is accordingly dismissed.
